GFS001.title: HACCP/APPCC System
GFS001.summary: The HACCP (Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points) system is the fundamental framework for food safety in hospitality. In Spain it's known as APPCC. Every food establishment must implement and maintain a documented APPCC plan identifying biological, chemical, and physical hazards at each stage of food handling. The plan must include critical control points, critical limits, monitoring procedures, corrective actions, and verification procedures.
keyPoints: Identify all food safety hazards in your establishment
Define critical control points (CCPs) for each process
Establish critical limits and monitoring procedures
Document corrective actions for each CCP
Maintain records and review the plan annually
Train all food handlers on APPCC principles
Display the APPCC plan in accessible locations

GFS002.title: Food Handler Certificate
GFS002.legalBasis: RD 109/2010 on food handler training requirements
GFS002.summary: All employees who handle food must hold a valid Food Handler Certificate (Carnet de Manipulador de Alimentos). Training must cover food hygiene, contamination prevention, allergen awareness, and personal hygiene. Certificates must be renewed as per regional regulations. The establishment must maintain copies of all certificates and ensure training is completed before staff begin handling food.
keyPoints: All food handlers must complete certified training
Keep copies of all certificates on file
Renew certificates as per regional requirements
New staff must be trained before handling food
Training covers hygiene, allergens, and contamination

GFS003.title: Temperature Control — Cold Chain
GFS003.legalBasis: RD 3484/2000 on hygiene standards for food preparation
GFS003.summary: Maintaining the cold chain is critical for food safety. Refrigerated products must be kept at 0-4°C and frozen products at -18°C or below. Temperature logs must be recorded at least twice daily. Any break in the cold chain requires immediate assessment and potential disposal of affected products.
keyPoints: Record temperatures at least twice daily
Check deliveries with probe thermometer on arrival
FIFO: First In, First Out rotation

GFS004.title: Temperature Control — Hot Holding
GFS004.summary: Hot food must be maintained at 65°C or above to prevent bacterial growth. Food that falls below this temperature for more than 2 hours must be discarded. Reheating must reach a core temperature of 75°C. Temperature logs for hot holding must be maintained.
keyPoints: Hot food must be held at 65°C or above
Discard food below 65°C for more than 2 hours
Reheat food to core temperature of 75°C

GFS005.title: Cleaning & Disinfection Plan
GFS005.summary: Every establishment must have a documented L+D (Limpieza y Desinfeccion) plan covering all areas, equipment, and surfaces. The plan specifies cleaning frequency, products, dilution rates, contact times, and responsible staff. Records of cleaning activities must be maintained.
keyPoints: Document cleaning procedures for every area
Specify products, dilutions, and contact times
Assign cleaning responsibilities to named staff
Separate cleaning equipment by zone (color coding)
Deep clean schedule for equipment and hard-to-reach areas

GFS006.title: Allergen Management
GFS006.legalBasis: EU Regulation 1169/2011 on food information to consumers
GFS006.summary: EU law requires clear communication of 14 major allergens in all food served. Staff must be trained to identify allergens in menu items and communicate them accurately to customers. Allergen information must be available in writing and staff must know cross-contamination prevention procedures.
keyPoints: Display allergen information for all menu items
Train all service staff on allergen communication
Have a protocol for allergic reaction emergencies
Update allergen info when recipes change

GFS007.title: Food Waste Prevention
GFS007.legalBasis: Ley 1/2025 de prevencion de las perdidas y el desperdicio alimentario
GFS007.summary: Spain's food waste law requires hospitality establishments to implement prevention plans, offer take-away options for unfinished meals, and maintain waste records. Establishments must prioritize donation of surplus food to authorized organizations before disposal.
keyPoints: Implement a food waste prevention plan
Offer take-away containers for unfinished meals
Maintain records of food waste quantities
Partner with food banks or donation platforms

GFS008.title: Traceability System
GFS008.summary: All food establishments must maintain a traceability system allowing identification of suppliers and products at every stage. This includes recording lot numbers, delivery dates, supplier details, and maintaining records for at least 5 years.
keyPoints: Record supplier details for all products
Maintain delivery notes with lot numbers and dates
Have a rapid recall procedure in place

GFS009.title: Supplier Control
GFS009.summary: Establishments must verify that all food suppliers are registered and comply with food safety regulations. A supplier approval process must be in place, including verification of health registrations, delivery conditions, and product quality.
keyPoints: Inspect products on arrival for quality

GFS010.title: Raw Material Reception
GFS010.summary: All deliveries must be inspected upon arrival for temperature compliance, packaging integrity, expiry dates, and organoleptic quality. Rejected products must be documented. Deliveries should be stored immediately in appropriate conditions.
keyPoints: Check expiry dates on all products

GFS011.title: Storage Procedures
GFS011.summary: Proper storage prevents contamination and spoilage. Raw and cooked products must be separated. FIFO rotation must be strictly followed. All containers must be covered and labeled with content and date. Storage areas must be clean and at correct temperatures.
keyPoints: Label all containers with content and date
Keep storage areas clean and organized
Never store food on the floor

GFS012.title: Cross-Contamination Prevention
GFS012.summary: Cross-contamination is a major food safety hazard. Prevention requires separation of raw and ready-to-eat foods, use of color-coded cutting boards, proper handwashing between tasks, and dedicated equipment for allergen-free preparation.
keyPoints: Use color-coded cutting boards and utensils
Separate raw and ready-to-eat foods at all times
Wash hands between handling different food types
Clean and sanitize work surfaces between tasks
Store raw products below cooked products

GFS013.title: Pest Control
GFS013.summary: A pest control program must be implemented by an authorized company. The establishment must maintain physical barriers, good housekeeping, and regular inspections. Records of pest control visits and any incidents must be kept.
keyPoints: Contract an authorized pest control company
Keep all areas clean and free of food debris
Keep pest control records on file

GFS014.title: Water Quality
GFS014.summary: Water used in food preparation must meet drinking water standards. If using a private water supply, regular testing is required. Ice machines must be maintained and cleaned according to manufacturer instructions.
keyPoints: Clean and maintain ice machines monthly
Use potable water for all food preparation

GFS015.title: Personal Hygiene for Food Handlers
GFS015.summary: Food handlers must maintain high standards of personal hygiene including handwashing, wearing clean uniforms, hair restraints, no jewelry, and reporting any illness that could affect food safety.
keyPoints: Wear clean uniform and hair restraint
Remove jewelry and watches before handling food
Cover cuts with blue waterproof plasters
Report illness, vomiting, or diarrhea to manager
Do not handle food when ill

GFS016.title: Sample Retention
GFS016.summary: Establishments serving more than a certain number of meals must retain representative samples of each dish served. Samples must be stored in labeled containers at appropriate temperatures for at least 72 hours.
keyPoints: Retain samples of all dishes served
Label with dish name, date, and time
Dispose of samples after retention period

GFS017.title: Defrost Procedures
GFS017.summary: Frozen products must be defrosted safely in the refrigerator, never at room temperature. Defrost time must be planned in advance. Once thawed, products must be used within 24 hours and never refrozen.

GFS018.title: Oil Quality Control
GFS018.summary: Frying oils must be monitored for degradation using polar compound tests. Oil exceeding 25% polar compounds must be replaced. Oil temperature must not exceed 180°C. Records of oil changes and test results must be maintained.
keyPoints: Test oil quality with polar compound meter
Replace oil when polar compounds exceed 25%
Filter oil daily and between different products
Record oil changes and test results

GFS019.title: Buffet & Display Food Safety
GFS019.summary: Food displayed in buffets must be maintained at safe temperatures. Hot food at 65°C+, cold food at 8°C or below. Display time must be limited and monitored. Sneeze guards must be in place.
keyPoints: Hot food at 65°C+, cold food at 8°C or below
Limit display time to maximum 4 hours
Use sneeze guards and covered containers
Replace rather than refill display items

GFS020.title: Delivery Food Safety
GFS020.summary: Food delivered to customers must maintain temperature control during transport. Insulated containers must be used. Delivery times must be minimized. Packaging must protect food from contamination.

GFS021.title: Microbiological Control
GFS021.summary: Regular microbiological testing of food, surfaces, and equipment helps verify the effectiveness of the APPCC system. Testing frequency and parameters must be defined in the food safety plan.
keyPoints: Schedule regular surface and food sampling
Define acceptance criteria based on EU standards
Take corrective action on non-compliant results

GFS022.title: Non-Conformity Management
GFS022.summary: When food safety standards are not met, a non-conformity management process must be followed. This includes identifying the issue, isolating affected products, investigating root cause, implementing corrective actions, and preventing recurrence.

GPRL001.title: PRL Prevention Plan
GPRL001.legalBasis: Ley 31/1995 de Prevencion de Riesgos Laborales
GPRL001.summary: Every employer must have a documented Occupational Risk Prevention Plan (Plan de PRL). This comprehensive document identifies all workplace hazards, establishes preventive measures, defines responsibilities, and outlines emergency procedures. It must be reviewed annually and whenever significant changes occur.
keyPoints: Define preventive measures for each risk

GPRL002.title: Risk Assessment
GPRL002.legalBasis: RD 39/1997 Reglamento de los Servicios de Prevencion
GPRL002.summary: A formal risk assessment must evaluate all workplace hazards specific to hospitality: burns, cuts, falls, manual handling, chemical exposure, and ergonomic risks. Each workstation and role must be assessed. Results inform the prevention plan and protective measures.
keyPoints: Assess risks for each workstation and role
Evaluate likelihood and severity of each hazard
Define control measures for each identified risk
Involve workers in the assessment process

GPRL003.title: PPE by Position
GPRL003.summary: Personal Protective Equipment requirements vary by role. Kitchen staff need cut-resistant gloves, non-slip shoes, and heat protection. Bar staff need non-slip footwear and eye protection for certain tasks. All staff need appropriate footwear for wet surfaces.
keyPoints: Kitchen: non-slip shoes, heat gloves, cut-resistant gloves
Bar: non-slip shoes, eye protection for chemicals
Train staff on correct use and maintenance

GPRL004.title: Emergency Plan
GPRL004.summary: An emergency plan must cover fire, medical emergencies, gas leaks, power failures, and natural disasters. It must include evacuation routes, assembly points, emergency contacts, and roles and responsibilities. Regular drills must be conducted.
keyPoints: Define procedures for all emergency types
Assign emergency roles (fire warden, first aider)

GPRL005.title: Evacuation Protocol
GPRL005.summary: Clear evacuation procedures must be established and practiced. Emergency exits must be clearly marked and unobstructed. Maximum occupancy must be respected. Staff must know their roles during evacuation including customer guidance and headcount.
keyPoints: Keep emergency exits clear at all times
Know the evacuation route from your workstation

GPRL006.title: First Aid
GPRL006.summary: First aid kits must be maintained and accessible. At least one trained first aider must be present per shift. The kit contents must be checked and replenished regularly. Common hospitality injuries include burns, cuts, falls, and allergic reactions.
keyPoints: Maintain stocked first aid kit in accessible location
At least one trained first aider per shift
Know location of nearest hospital and emergency number (112)

GPRL007.title: Kitchen Ergonomics
GPRL007.summary: Kitchen work involves prolonged standing, repetitive movements, and heavy lifting. Ergonomic measures include anti-fatigue mats, adjustable work surfaces, proper lifting techniques, and regular breaks. Work organization should minimize repetitive strain.
keyPoints: Adjust work surface heights where possible
Rotate tasks to reduce repetitive strain

GPRL008.title: Manual Handling
GPRL008.legalBasis: RD 487/1997 on manual handling of loads
GPRL008.summary: Manual handling of heavy items (deliveries, kegs, equipment) is a major cause of workplace injury. Maximum recommended weight is 25kg. Staff must be trained in safe lifting techniques. Mechanical aids should be provided where possible.
keyPoints: Use correct lifting technique: bend knees, straight back
Use trolleys and mechanical aids when available
Ask for help with heavy or awkward loads
Store heavy items at waist height
Report any back pain or injury immediately

GPRL009.title: Chemical Products Handling
GPRL009.summary: Cleaning chemicals, degreasers, and sanitizers must be handled safely. Safety Data Sheets must be available for all products. Staff must wear appropriate PPE. Chemicals must be stored separately from food in labeled containers. Never mix different chemicals.
keyPoints: Read Safety Data Sheets before using any product
Keep chemicals in original labeled containers
Know the location of eye wash station

GPRL010.title: Thermal Stress Prevention
GPRL010.summary: Kitchen environments can reach extreme temperatures. Prevention measures include adequate ventilation, access to water, rotation between hot and cool areas, appropriate clothing, and monitoring for heat stress symptoms.
keyPoints: Ensure adequate ventilation in kitchen areas
Provide free access to drinking water
Rotate between hot and cool stations
Monitor staff for heat stress symptoms
Allow additional breaks in extreme heat

GPRL011.title: Noise Exposure
GPRL011.summary: Bar and event environments can exceed safe noise levels (85 dB). Noise assessments must be conducted. Hearing protection must be provided for staff in loud environments. Music volume limits may apply per local ordinance.
keyPoints: Limit continuous exposure to loud music
Position staff away from speakers where possible

GPRL012.title: Electrical Safety
GPRL012.summary: All electrical equipment must be properly maintained and inspected. Staff must not use damaged cables or equipment. Water and electricity areas must be properly separated. Only qualified technicians may perform electrical repairs.
keyPoints: Keep water away from electrical equipment
Use only qualified electricians for repairs
Know location of main electrical switch

GPRL013.title: Fire Prevention
GPRL013.legalBasis: RD 513/2017 Reglamento de Instalaciones de Proteccion contra Incendios
GPRL013.summary: Fire prevention in hospitality requires proper maintenance of fire suppression systems, clear access to extinguishers, regular staff training, and strict kitchen protocols for grease fires and gas equipment.
keyPoints: Know location and use of fire extinguishers
Maintain fire suppression hood systems in kitchen
Keep fire exits clear and accessible
Never throw water on grease fires

GPRL014.title: Gas Safety
GPRL014.summary: Gas installations must be inspected regularly by authorized technicians. Staff must know how to detect gas leaks (smell, hissing), shut off gas supply, and evacuate. Gas equipment must be maintained according to manufacturer specifications.
keyPoints: Know how to detect a gas leak
Know location of gas shut-off valve
Evacuate immediately if gas leak suspected
Never use open flame to check for leaks

GPRL015.title: Pregnancy & Lactation Protection
GPRL015.summary: Pregnant and breastfeeding workers are entitled to risk assessment of their specific role, adaptation of working conditions, and exemption from night shifts and hazardous tasks. If adaptation is not possible, temporary reassignment must be offered.
keyPoints: Conduct specific risk assessment for pregnant workers
Adapt working conditions to eliminate risks
Exempt from night shifts if medically advised
Avoid exposure to chemicals, heavy lifting, prolonged standing
Offer temporary reassignment if risks cannot be eliminated

GPRL016.title: Young Worker Protection
GPRL016.legalBasis: Ley 31/1995, RD 1/1995 Estatuto de los Trabajadores
GPRL016.summary: Workers under 18 have additional protections: no night work, limited working hours, specific risk assessment, and prohibition from dangerous tasks. Working hours must not exceed 8 hours per day including training time.

GPRL017.title: Night Work Health Surveillance
GPRL017.summary: Night workers (22:00-06:00) are entitled to periodic health surveillance. The employer must assess specific health risks of night work and offer free medical examinations. Transfer to day work must be offered if health issues arise.
keyPoints: Offer periodic health checks to night workers
Assess specific risks of night work
Transfer to day work if health issues arise
Maximum 8 hours average in any 15-day period

GPRL018.title: Psychosocial Risk Prevention
GPRL018.summary: Psychosocial risks include work-related stress, burnout, harassment, and work-life imbalance. Prevention measures include reasonable workloads, clear communication, anti-harassment protocols, and support systems. These risks must be included in the risk assessment.
keyPoints: Include psychosocial risks in risk assessment
Train managers to recognize stress signs

GLAB001.title: Collective Agreement (Convenio Colectivo)
GLAB001.summary: The Convenio Colectivo de Hosteleria sets minimum conditions for the sector including pay scales, working hours, overtime, holidays, and professional categories. The applicable agreement depends on the province. All employment conditions must meet or exceed the convenio minimums.
keyPoints: Minimum conditions cannot be reduced by contract
Pay scales by professional category apply
Working time limits are legally binding
Display the convenio reference in the workplace

GLAB002.title: Working Hours & Rest Periods
GLAB002.summary: Maximum working week is 40 hours averaged annually. Maximum daily shift is 9 hours. Minimum rest between shifts is 12 hours. A minimum 15-minute break is required for shifts over 6 hours. Weekly rest minimum is 1.5 consecutive days.
keyPoints: Maximum 9 hours per day (unless convenio allows more)

GLAB003.title: Overtime Regulations
GLAB003.summary: Overtime hours must be voluntary (except force majeure). Maximum 80 overtime hours per year. Overtime must be compensated with either pay (minimum 175% per convenio) or equivalent time off within 4 months. All overtime must be recorded.
keyPoints: Compensate at 175% or with time off
Time off must be taken within 4 months
Part-time workers: overtime has specific rules

GLAB004.title: Vacation Rights
GLAB004.summary: All workers are entitled to a minimum of 30 natural days (22 working days) of paid vacation per year. Vacation dates must be agreed between employer and employee. At least one period must be 2 consecutive weeks. Vacation cannot overlap with sick leave.
keyPoints: At least 2 consecutive weeks in one period
Vacation schedule agreed by both parties

GLAB005.title: Time Recording (Registro de Jornada)
GLAB005.summary: Since 2019, all employers must record the daily start and end time of each worker. Records must be kept for 4 years. The system must be reliable and accessible to workers and labor inspectors. Failure to comply can result in fines of 626-6,250 euros.
keyPoints: Record daily start and end times for all staff
System must be reliable and verifiable
Workers must have access to their records
Available for labor inspection at any time

GLAB006.title: Contract Types in Hospitality
GLAB006.summary: The 2021 labor reform significantly changed contract types. Indefinite contracts are now the default. Fixed-term contracts are limited to specific circumstances (production peaks, substitution). Discontinuous fixed contracts (fijo discontinuo) are common in seasonal hospitality.
keyPoints: Fixed-term only for specific legal causes
Fijo discontinuo for seasonal recurring work
Part-time contracts must specify exact hours

GLAB007.title: Worker Rights & Duties
GLAB007.summary: Workers have fundamental rights including fair pay, non-discrimination, dignity at work, health and safety, trade union membership, and information/consultation. Duties include good faith, diligence, compliance with safety rules, and confidentiality.
keyPoints: Right to fair and timely pay
Right to non-discrimination and equal treatment
Right to occupational health and safety
Duty to comply with safety instructions
Duty to act in good faith

GLAB008.title: Understanding Your Payroll
GLAB008.summary: Understanding your nomina (payroll) is important. It shows base salary, complementos (supplements), overtime, deductions (IRPF, Social Security), and net pay. The payroll must be provided monthly. Any discrepancies should be reported promptly.
keyPoints: IRPF withholding depends on personal situation
Two extra payments (pagas extra) per year

GLAB009.title: Social Security
GLAB009.legalBasis: Ley General de la Seguridad Social (RD Legislativo 8/2015)
GLAB009.summary: All employed workers must be registered with Social Security. Contributions cover healthcare, pensions, unemployment, and sick leave. The employer is responsible for registration and contribution payments. Workers should verify their working life report (Informe de Vida Laboral) periodically.
keyPoints: Registration is mandatory from day one
Check your Vida Laboral report periodically
Report any irregularities to Social Security
Keep your Social Security number safe

GROL001.title: Kitchen Fire Safety
GROL001.summary: Kitchen fires are the most common type in hospitality. Grease fires require special extinguishing methods — never use water. Kitchen hoods must have automatic fire suppression. Fire blankets must be accessible. Gas shut-off procedures must be known by all kitchen staff.
keyPoints: Never use water on grease fires
Know location and use of fire blanket
Kitchen hood fire suppression must be maintained
Keep extinguisher accessible (Class F for grease)
Clean hood filters regularly to prevent grease buildup

GROL002.title: Kitchen Knife Safety
GROL002.summary: Knife injuries are among the most common in kitchens. Prevention requires proper training, use of sharp knives (dull knives are more dangerous), appropriate cutting techniques, cut-resistant gloves for certain tasks, and proper storage.
keyPoints: Use sharp knives — dull knives slip more
Use cut-resistant gloves for deboning and similar
Store knives in designated racks or blocks
Never leave knives in sinks or submerged in water
Carry knives point-down at your side

GROL003.title: Kitchen Burns Prevention
GROL003.summary: Burns from hot surfaces, liquids, steam, and oil are frequent kitchen hazards. Prevention includes proper PPE (heat-resistant gloves, long sleeves), awareness of hot surfaces, proper pot handling techniques, and immediate first aid for burns.
keyPoints: Use heat-resistant gloves when handling hot items
Turn pot handles inward on the stove
Open lids away from you to avoid steam burns
Keep a burns kit accessible in kitchen
First aid: cool water 10+ minutes, do not use ice

GROL004.title: Kitchen Ventilation
GROL004.summary: Adequate ventilation is essential for kitchen safety and comfort. Extraction hoods must be properly sized and maintained. Air supply must balance extraction. Filters must be cleaned regularly to prevent grease buildup and fire risk.
keyPoints: Monitor CO levels in gas kitchens

GROL005.title: Kitchen Equipment Safety
GROL005.summary: Kitchen equipment (slicers, mixers, fryers, ovens) must be used according to manufacturer instructions. Staff must be trained on each piece of equipment. Safety guards must never be removed. Equipment must be properly maintained and inspected.
keyPoints: Turn off and unplug before cleaning
Keep hands clear of moving parts

GROL006.title: Responsible Alcohol Service
GROL006.legalBasis: Ley 5/2018 (varies by region), Ley 26/2015 child protection
GROL006.summary: Bar staff must serve alcohol responsibly. This includes refusing service to minors (under 18), recognizing signs of intoxication, and having protocols for refusing service. Staff must know the legal liability of serving intoxicated persons.
keyPoints: Check ID if age is uncertain
Know how to refuse service diplomatically
Offer water and food to intoxicated customers

GROL007.title: Bar Glassware Handling
GROL007.summary: Broken glass is a significant hazard in bar environments. Proper handling, storage, and cleanup procedures minimize risk. Never pick up broken glass with bare hands. Use designated containers for broken glass.
keyPoints: Inspect glasses for chips and cracks before use
Never pick up broken glass with bare hands
Use brush and dustpan or damp cloth
Use separate bin for broken glass
Never use glass to scoop ice

GROL008.title: Dining Room Tray Handling
GROL008.summary: Proper tray handling prevents injuries and spillage. Training in correct carrying technique, load distribution, and route awareness is essential. Heavy trays should be supported by both hands.
keyPoints: Distribute weight evenly on the tray
Support heavy trays with both hands
Be aware of your route and obstacles
Use tray stands for heavy loads
Watch for wet floors and uneven surfaces

GROL009.title: Dining Room Slip Prevention
GROL009.summary: Slip and fall accidents are common in hospitality. Prevention requires non-slip footwear, immediate cleanup of spills, proper floor maintenance, and clear signage for wet areas.
keyPoints: Wear non-slip shoes at all times
Place wet floor signs when cleaning
Be extra cautious in kitchen-to-dining transitions

GROL010.title: Anti-Harassment Protocol
GROL010.summary: Every company must have an anti-harassment protocol covering sexual harassment, harassment based on sex, and workplace bullying. The protocol must include prevention measures, complaint procedures, investigation process, and sanctions. All staff must be informed.
keyPoints: Zero tolerance for all forms of harassment
All complaints will be investigated confidentially
Sanctions range from warning to dismissal

GROL011.title: Equality Plan
GROL011.summary: Companies with 50+ employees must have an Equality Plan. Even smaller companies must respect equal treatment principles. The plan addresses equal pay, recruitment, promotion, work-life balance, and sexual harassment prevention.
keyPoints: Equal access to training and promotion
Regular monitoring and review of equality indicators

GROL012.title: Digital Disconnection Right
GROL012.legalBasis: LO 3/2018 LOPDGDD Art. 88, ET Art. 20 bis
GROL012.summary: Workers have the right to digital disconnection outside working hours. Employers cannot require staff to answer emails, messages, or calls during rest periods. An internal policy must be established defining the terms of this right.
keyPoints: No obligation to respond to work messages outside hours
Respect rest periods and vacation time
Policy must be communicated to all staff

GROL013.title: Workplace Bullying Prevention
GROL013.summary: Workplace bullying (acoso laboral) includes repeated hostile behavior that creates an intimidating or degrading work environment. Prevention requires clear policies, reporting channels, investigation procedures, and a supportive work culture.
keyPoints: Report any incidents through official channels

GROL014.title: Data Protection (GDPR/LOPDGDD)
GROL014.summary: Staff handle personal data of customers and colleagues. GDPR compliance requires understanding data minimization, consent, secure storage, and individuals' rights. Employee data (schedules, payroll, health) must be protected.
keyPoints: Never share personal data without authorization

GDOC001.title: Mandatory Documentation Checklist
GDOC001.summary: This checklist covers all documentation legally required for a hospitality establishment: food safety records, PRL documentation, employment records, health registrations, licenses, insurance, and regulatory certifications.

GDOC002.title: Training Records
GDOC002.summary: All training provided to staff must be documented. Records must include training topic, date, duration, trainer, attendees, and content. Both food safety and occupational health training records must be maintained and available for inspection.
keyPoints: Record all training sessions with dates and content
Maintain attendance records signed by participants
Keep certificates and qualifications on file
Document induction training for new staff

GDOC003.title: Annual Training Plan
GDOC003.summary: An annual training plan ensures all staff receive necessary food safety, health and safety, and skills training. The plan should identify training needs, schedule sessions, allocate budget, and track completion.
keyPoints: Assess training needs for each role
Schedule training sessions throughout the year

GDOC004.title: Health Inspection Preparation
GDOC004.summary: Health inspections can occur without notice. Preparation requires maintaining all food safety documentation up to date, ensuring the premises meet hygiene standards, and having designated staff who can assist inspectors.
keyPoints: Keep all food safety documentation current
Ensure APPCC records are up to date
Know who is responsible for accompanying inspectors

GDOC005.title: Labor Inspection Preparation
GDOC005.legalBasis: Ley 23/2015 de la Inspeccion de Trabajo
GDOC005.summary: Labor inspections verify compliance with employment law, health and safety, and social security. Inspectors can arrive unannounced. Key documents that must be available include contracts, time records, payroll, PRL plan, and social security registrations.
keyPoints: Time recording system must be operational
Payroll records available for current year
Know who is authorized to liaise with inspectors

GENV001.title: Waste Management
GENV001.legalBasis: Ley 7/2022 de residuos y suelos contaminados
GENV001.summary: Spain's waste law requires businesses to minimize, separate, and properly dispose of waste. Hospitality establishments must separate at minimum: organic, packaging, glass, paper/cardboard, and used oil. Waste records must be maintained.
keyPoints: Train all staff on waste separation

GENV002.title: Waste Separation Protocol
GENV002.summary: Proper waste separation is both a legal obligation and environmental responsibility. Each waste type has designated containers and collection schedules. Staff must be trained to separate correctly. Contaminated waste fractions reduce recycling effectiveness.

GENV003.title: Used Oil Management
GENV003.summary: Used cooking oil must never be poured down drains. It must be collected in designated containers and picked up by authorized recycling companies. Records of oil disposal must be maintained. One liter of oil can contaminate 1,000 liters of water.
keyPoints: Never pour oil down the drain
Collect used oil in designated containers
Store oil containers in a secure area

GENV004.title: Energy Efficiency
GENV004.summary: Energy efficiency reduces costs and environmental impact. Key measures include LED lighting, efficient equipment, temperature management, preventive maintenance, and staff awareness of energy-saving practices.
keyPoints: Turn off equipment when not in use

GENV005.title: Food Waste Reduction Program
GENV005.summary: Beyond legal compliance, a food waste reduction program demonstrates environmental responsibility. It includes waste auditing, menu planning to minimize waste, staff training on portions, composting where possible, and partnerships with food donation organizations.
keyPoints: Audit food waste to identify main sources
Plan menus to use ingredients efficiently
Train staff on correct portion sizes
Set waste reduction targets and monitor progress
